title: Do archaeologists have a tendency to simply label artifacts of unknown purpose 'ceremonial'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes and no. You throw up a few questions - what exactly makes a ritual or ceremonial object, and is that a valid interpretation? And why does so much archaeological news seem to consist of these objects? I’ll try to address both. Calling something ‘ritual’ is a sort of a joke amongst archaeologists. It’s a quick way of describing a behaviour, feature or object that can’t be easily given a functional explanation. Archaeology, particularly prehistory, is rife with ‘ritual’ phenomena and is not limited to ‘mysterious’ objects or monumental structures. Ditches comprising enclosures or field systems, structural foundations like post-holes or beam slots, walls, wells and storage pits are all pretty understandable features; they serve a purpose we can understand. Ceramic pots, metal brooches, coins and butchered animal bones are all similarly functional in nature. Finding large broken sherds of pot and animal bones in the bottom of a pit is an example of finding a functional behaviour. We can interpret the deposition of these artefacts as being the primary discard of rubbish - pots that have broken, butchered bones, thrown into a pit to be gotten rid of.  An Iron Age loom weight, recycled from a broken pot base. But finding a complete, unbroken pot in a pit or at the bottom of a ditch, or a complete animal grave of a cow or pig, could be examples of ritual deposition, because there’s no functional reason you’d want to do that, at least to our modern-day minds and sensibilities.  Teracotta votive bodyparts.  A votive amphora from sussex. Deposition of votive offerings is a practice found across the world throughout history. The Romans deposited miniature objects and curse tablets (rolled-up lead inscriptions) into sacred springs, wells and pits. The vikings cast ‘ritually killed’ swords into bogs. Prehistoric people were buried with grave goods including food, jewellery and other objects.  A reconstruction of the Amesbury Archer grave. There are objects and practices which are unambigiously ritual. Structures like Stonehenge, the Pyramids and causewayed enclosures are all held up as ritual monuments, because they serve no functional purpose such as for shelter or storage. It is a matter of semantics whether you consider the feasting and celebration that occurred at places like Stonehenge to be important functional requirements for prehistoric societies. One of the great debates in archaeology is whether past people were rational. This just means they reacted in rational ways to their environment and always took the best-fit solution to problems such as how to expend their labour or build their settlements. We’ve largely moved past this simplistic, purely processual view, and tend to understand that if people don’t always act in the most rational way today, there’s no reason they would back then. Just because we don’t see a ‘logical’ interpretation for something we find, doesn’t mean that it’s not valid. A wise piece of advice I was given when I first entered archaeology was ‘Don’t seek to fathom the wisdom of the ancients’ - strange given that’s all archaeologists try to do, but it just means that because something doesn’t make ‘sense’, doesn’t mean that isn’t what it is. When I’ve found things like a square pit lined with re-used Roman roof tiles and filled with rubble and bone gaming tokens, I think ‘Don’t seek to fathom the wisdom of the ancients’. On to the second question - why is such a big deal made of ritual objects and sites? Why are they the big-ticket items that make the news? The simple answer is that they’re sexy. They are, by-and-large, what the general public wants to read about, so that’s what the news caters to. They may be three hundred archaeological sites being excavated in the UK on any day of the week. Some of them will find things that are interesting.. to other archaeologists. Occasionally they find things that are interesting to non-archaeologists.  An Anglo-Saxon plank-lined grave in the news recently. Remains of this sort and level of preservation are very rare. A big deal was made out of one of the coffins on this site being a hollowed-out tree trunk. Do you think that is a ritual behaviour? These sites tend to be photogenic, involve mosaics or human remains, and the people that find them have strong media instincts. The more remote something is from our present-day understanding or way of life, the more ‘mysterious’ an object is.. well.. the better news it makes.

I always found it amusing that every piece of armour or weaponry that is decorated is immediately called a parade armour or ornamental despite being fully functional. An example would be this mask found at the site of the battle of Teutenborg forest  Archaeologists were fast to label it as a parade piece not worn during battle.  It apparently slipped their mind that people went into battle dressed like this less than two centuries ago

There is a book called Motel of the Mysteries that covers this subject. It is humorous and enlightening. You can get it on Amazon, if you are interested. My thought, not being an archaeologist by any means, is how do you get a bunch of people to do an enormous amount of work to which there is very little evident purpose? You pay them exorbitant amounts of money or say it is for GOD! Take more modern marvels such as cathedrals and Hagga Sophia and the like where we KNOW they are for religious purposes. Same with the Pyramids which ARE NOT GRANARIES!

It's kind of an in joke amongst archaeologists. If we don't know what it means we generally label it as symbolic in some sense - not necessarily ritual though, that would depend on a number of factors.
